results.title: Bunny
results.creator_credit: Western Australia Film Council, Philip Ellery and Edwin James Lynch
results.brief_description: A young girl, Jane (Tamara Liffers), left to her own devices at home proceeds to go about her morning ritual. She feeds herself, her pet fish and dog then goes to secretly feed the next door neighbour’s pet rabbit. Jane hides when she spots Mrs. Nextdoor (Tiffany Evans) entering the garden who unbeknowns to her is about to bury the dead rabbit. Jane panics when her dog has brought in the dead carcus of the rabbit believing that the dog has killed the rabbit. Jane’s matter of fact approach to right the situation illustrates the naivity and simplicity of a child’s mind. Cast also includes Ivor Bowen.

results.title: Bunker Hill, 1956
results.creator_credit: University of Southern California, Merl Edelman and Kent Mackenzie
results.brief_description: A study of the people who live in the downtown section of Los Angeles called Bunker Hill. Presents a typical day in their lives and the problems they must face when uprooted by the razing of the section for building offices. Uses recorded voices of the residents. Makes a plea for the preservation of Bunker Hill.

results.title: Buma: African sculpture speaks
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Henry R. Cassirer
results.brief_description: Twenty different antique sculptures from Central and West Africa are used to illustrate the important part played by carved wooden statues and masks in the everyday life of native Africans. The use of masks as protection or reassurance against common dangers and fears is dramatised with the assistance of tribal drum music actually recorded in Africa. Antique sculpture used in the film is from the Segy Galleries, New York.

results.title: Bulworth
results.creator_credit: Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, Warren Beatty and Pieter Jan Brugge
results.brief_description: Set in 1996 at the time of the Bill Clinton re-election era, “Bulworth” is a political satire about one man’s re-invigorated will and desire to live. Bulworth (Warren Beatty) is a corrupt senator, campaigning for re-election within a system dominated by business investments, right-wing interests and concerns of the wealthy. Jaded, depressed, disillusioned and disgusted with himself and those around him, Bulworth takes out life insurance of 10 million dollars then orders a hit on himself. The knowledge that he only has 48 hours to live spurs Bulworth to speak freely and honestly to his constituents, laying bare the corruption, greed and self-serving nature of American politics. The fallout from these events is mammoth and quite unexpected for Bulworth and those that surround him. Bulworth’s revived will to live honestly and with integrity is reflected in his embracing of Afro-American rap culture, a move that confounds his staff and the public. “Bulworth” astounded audiences upon it release with its sharp and witty script, and scathing denouncing of American politics. Beatty won an Oscar nomination for his script that he collaborated on with Jeremy Pikser.

results.title: Bully for hockey
results.creator_credit: Moving Picture Company, Film Australia, Peter Johnson and Ivan Hexter
results.brief_description: General interest film focusing on all age levels of men’s and women’s hockey within Doncaster Hockey Club. Includes training, fitness, social aspects. Suitable for secondary years 7-12.

results.title: Bully [DVD] (D)
results.creator_credit: Studio Canal France, Don Murphy, Fernando Sulichin, Chris Hanley and Larry Clark
results.brief_description: Not one to shy from contentious content, Larry Clark followed the success and infamy of “Kids” (1995) and “Another day in paradise” (1997) with the equally controversial “Bully”, based on the true story of the trial of a group of Florida teenagers charged with murdering a friend. The film stars a cast barely out of their teens themselves (in fact, some still are): Brad Renfro, Rachel Miner, Bijou Phillips, Nick Stahl and Kelli Garner, a fact not lost on Clark in casting. High school drop out and keen surfer Marty (Renfro), and pal Bobby (Stahl), have been friends since age four and throughout that period Marty has been victimised physically and verbally by his so called best friend. Marty and Bobby invite Lisa and Ali out to a “party” and a sexual relationship develops between the four that is punctuated by violence and violation. Lisa discovers she is pregnant to Marty (or is it Bobby?), in love with him, and can no longer stand Bobby’s behaviour towards Marty, vowing to have him killed. Constructing a posse of misfit delinquents comprising a Mafia hitman, lovelorn games and acid addicted cousin, dope-smoker and suicidal young sexpot, head out to the everglades to complete the task. An exploitative expose of disenfranchised teens whose ennui and lack of parental guidance allow deviant behaviour and a loss of childhood innocence. Adapted from journalist Jim Schutze’s novel, “Bully: a true story of high school revenge”.

results.title: Bulls
results.brief_description: Adaptation of an Alan Marshall story of a young girl’s isolation on a remote dairy farm, set in the late 1930s. Atmospheric, this production adds another dimension to the Marshall piece, although it lacks the “Laurentian” dimension of “Boys and girls”.

results.title: Bullocky
results.creator_credit: Australian Commonwealth Film Unit, Richard Mitchell and Gil Brealey
results.brief_description: Vic Deaves is a fourth generation bushman. For as long as he can remember, his family has lived in and off the Australian bush, often as timber-getters in the coastal valleys of New South Wales. Vic is a bullocky, one of the last of his kind. In this film Vic talks about his life and work, his bullocks and his friends. The area where he works is very much a part of another Australia, now past, but Vic and his surroundings represent the best of it.

results.title: Bullitt
results.creator_credit: Solar Productions, Philip D'Antoni and Peter Yates
results.brief_description: Steve McQueen plays the title role as Frank Bullitt, a no-glitter, all-guts cop who is assigned to protect Chicago gangster Johnny Ross (Pat Renella), who is scheduled to testify against his mob cronies in San Francisco. But after Ross is attacked and later killed at the hospital, Bullitt conceals Ross’s death and begins to investigate the case himself, sensing something suspicious. One of the most memorable scenes in Bullitt is the celebrated car chase through the streets of San Francisco. McQueen, an expert automobile and motorcycle racer, does his own stunt driving as he propels his high-performance Mustang around and over San Francisco’s fabled hills. Cast includes Jacqueline Bisset, Robert Vaughn, Don Gordon and Robert Duvall.
